newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Australia, Philippines set formal security talks.
newsitem.headline: Australia, Philippines set formal security talks.

text.p: Australia and the Philippines on Tuesday announced closer cooperation in three areas, including the establishment of formal bilateral security talks, foreign ministers from the two countries said.

"We're upgrading our security (ties) by establishing bilateral regional security talks (with the Philippines)," Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, said at a joint news briefing with Philippine Foreign Secretary Domingo Siazon.
The talks would "allow discussion of regional security issues", with the first meetings to be held later this year, Downer said.
Australia already holds formal bilateral security talks with the United States, China, Japan and South Korea.

Asked if disputes by several Asian countries over territories in the South China Sea would be part of the bilateral talks, Siazon said "...the South China Sea issue is one of the more, I would say, prominent subjects dealt with every year ..."
But he added that all areas of potential conflict in the region would be discussed.

Another area of closer cooperation will be through the start of a Philippines-Australia dialogue that will bring together "business people, academics and politicians to flesh out new ideas for the future", Downer said. Both foreign ministers will also participate in the dialogue.

In addition, Australia will conduct a survey of Australian investments in the Philippines and use the findings to "highlight new areas of opportunity for Australian business, as well as identify problems and obstacles to our investment relationships", Downer said.
He said trade between the countries had grown 130 percent since 1991.
As part of the Philippine-Australia dialogue, Siazon will make his first visit to Australia in his role as foreign secretary in August. Downer will go to Manila in October, the ministers said.
Both ministers have been in Malaysia's capital city for the week-long Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) 30th anniversary meetings, which wrap up on Tuesday.

The regional grouping consists of Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. Australia is one of 10 ASEAN dialogue partners of key Western and Asian powers.
